fields.Title of Contribution: <p><span style="font-size:11pt;">Building a practice ready and resilient nursing workforce</span></p>
fields.Description/Abstract: <p><span>Nurse leaders depend upon resiliency skills to support their practice. It is important to provide </span><span>opportunities for nursing students to learn, practice, and observe these skills, which are needed </span><span>to navigate challenging work environments. This article describes the impact of a resiliency </span><span>curricular component in a grant-funded BSN elective course, Concepts of Primary Care. Program </span><span>evaluation was performed using a pre/posttest format and 2 surveys, the Brief Resilience Scale </span><span>(BRS) and the Brief Resilience Coping Scale (BRCS). Three open-ended questions were administered upon completion of the elective course. A concurrent nested design was utilized with </span><span>a thematic analysis undertaken to analyze qualitative data. Analysis of quantitative data was</span><br><span>performed using descriptive statistics. Undergraduate BSN students showed an overall increase </span><span>in resiliency (BRS: P = .112; BCRS: P = .064), and responses to open-ended questions supported </span><span>the ability to apply and analyze most of the resiliency skills presented during the didactic portion </span><span>of the elective course. This course promoted the development and refinement of undergraduate </span><span>BSN student resilience skills. Integration of resilience content in the primary care course also </span><span>supported student professional development. The addition of resiliency concepts and skills into</span><br><span>undergraduate nursing curricula is recommended to enhance the ability of novice nurses to </span><span>address work-related challenges and promote career satisfaction for the future. Key words: BSN </span><span>students, curriculum, nursing workforce, primary care, resilience</span><span> </span><br><span>doi: 10.1097/NAQ.0000000000000631</span></p>
